review_blob: pours clear with a light orange body and minimal head.  smells of citrus, particularly orange...good carbonation - present, but not overly fizzy...received for x-mas so cant comment on cost/taste benefit - but this is definitely worth being priced the same as your other micros/crafts...smooth after taste with not a hint of alcohol going down...

Poured pitch black with a brown head (pint glass) - head remained a good number of minutes...smells like thick homebrew burnt and heavy.  Sweeter than I anticipated...I think of stouts as dry, but maybe thats the imperial shining through?  Nonetheless, smooth going down without betraying the abv...an oily mouth feel lingers, but not too long - a mighty nice new years brew...no discernible hops to speak of which is a good thing - but a hint of bitterness in the after taste too....

Poured cloudier than most IPAs and not much of a head to speak of with my pour.  Solid mouth feel with after taste of orange juice.  Not as hoppy as I expected given the name, but definitely pegged as an IPA - good brew, but there are a lot more IPAs out there that cost the same and taste better...

beer_brewer_name: Schneider Weisse G. Schneider & Sohn GmbH
review_blob: Relative to its older brother, (my highest rated brew, by the way), this is hot - you can taste an alcohol burn going down which, imho, rates a bit of a downgrade...nonetheless, still a very complicated nose and taste of fruits - esp. banana.  I also like the fact that it still retained a lot of the yeast sediment.

24 oz bomber...12th season release...pale copper pour with amazing head retention...thick and foamy...I really like the wet hops concept - puts one over on the homebrewer who has to buy pellet or flower that are nowhere near same day picked or pelletized!  Full mouthfeel with tastes of lemon and pine.  Nice!
beer_name: Sierra Nevada Harvest Wet Hop IPA - Northern Hemisphere

review_blob: A solid beer with a copper pour and minimal head retention.  Rather sweet for a pale ale - had this been a blind tasting, I would have pegged it as a marzen or Oktoberfest brew.  Not much going on in terms of aroma hops, but bitter enough so as to say a pale ale, you say?  Well, I guess so...  An additional positive - no resinous after taste which is all too common with pale ales or (moreso) with IPAs.  Ill buy this again....

Pours a light orange with a small head - very noticeable aroma of hops, and one of the top four or five smelling beers Ive had the pleasure to drink - but, the hop taste (again, very full and front and center) reminds me of pelletized hops in a home brew. These taste just fine, but it seems a bit contradictory given this beers subtitle "fresh hop ale".  The main difference in the taste of a pelletized hop vs a flowering hop (imho) is that the pelletized hop gives a little less full mouthfeel and is a tad more astringent.  Nonetheless, this is an extremely tasty, drinkable ad infinitum brew that makes me think New Zealand may be to hops what Australia has been to Shiraz of late.  A definite repeat winning beer....
beer_name: Sierra Nevada Harvest Fresh Hop IPA - Southern Hemisphere

review_blob: An upper tier beer...pours dark with a compact head reminiscent of Guinness draught - smells smoky and sour.  Full mouth feel with an appropriate amount of carbonation.  An after taste of cherry tobacco is present, but subtle enough to be a plus instead of a distraction.  If I was served this in a blind tasting, I would have said it was either a rich stout or a heavy Scotch ale.  I always thought imperial referred to a heavier abv%, but this one comes in at a respectable 8% - definitely not shooting for the barley wine  percentages and it shows as there is no hot taste associated with this brew.  I dont taste the vanilla advertised, and Im thinking the sour note I detect is the oak?  Regardless, a tasty brew and one worth revisiting....

The label on my bottle differs from the picture online - mine had a red baron looking dude surrounded by wheat/wattle??  Anyway, just another tasty beer as far as Im concerned - still dont know what a wattle is and couldnt really taste anything unique - in my opinion, this was a decent brown ale with a hint of clove - tasty, but nothing really special...

Pours a cloudy tan with a dense head - aromas of honey and maple (maybe thats the hazelnut??) A bit under carbonated relative to a lot of ales, but it worked for this brew - allowing the malty flavor to shine through without blasting you with bubbles.  The malt presence reminds me of unprocessed malt extract you lick off the cans when making home-brew - heavier sweetness than a lot of beer, but not overdone.  Good brew

Poured more of a cola color than a true red, but isnt that the case with most red-ales?  Small head, grainy aroma.  Medium bodied mouth feel, but tasty with the exception of a bit of an odd, sourish after-taste that diminishes proportionally with the number of bottles consumed :)  I liked it and would be interested to see how it tastes out of tap at the brewery as opposed to the bottles bought from the local Harris Teeter in Chesapeake, about 80 miles +/- to the south.

Pours a cloudy orange with a light head that dissipates quickly.  Smells of citrus - noticeably grapefruit.  Tastes tart with little carbonation - like poured draught - I really like this beer and think it has only one drawback - its got a bit of slick tongue coating that remains after swallowing...its why I dinged the palate portion.  Other than that, though, a great beer.

This beer is what Ive always aspired to as a home brewer - a deceptive abv% relative to taste, a translucent, but not cloudy, pour (albeit no decent head to speak of) and a malty, sweet taste with just the right amount of carbonation - not quite up there with your standard pilseners, but not as reserved as a porter...a really nice medium.  The only drawback, in my opinion, is the price relative to the product...for half the price and 2/3 the taste, you could buy a Shiner Bock or even an Amber Bock (alright, 1/3 the taste) albeit with a little less kick...

Bottle #1142 of 2007 - Poured slightly cloudy and opaque.  Decent head that lingers - off white with large carbonation pockets.  Smells sweet with slight nuances of raisin.  Not much of a hop presence in the aroma.  Rich and impressive first taste - sweet, malty - the commercial deScription talks about the hops - but rather than impart a distinct taste, I think they do a better job evening out the whopping malt presence.  Not at all bitter.  A slight alcoholic after taste which I believe is probably much higher than detected (didnt see an abv% on the bottle or in the deScription - Im guessing 8-9% range??).  This is a brew I hope is replicated as well next go round....
beer_name: AleWerks Brewmasters Reserve Wolfes Trap Ale

review_blob: Poured dark with a compact head that was slightly off white with no discernible lacing. Smells earthy Tastes reminiscent of BBQ sauce (I dont mean that in a pejorative way) Im willing to bet this would complement a pork roast really well...Very full mouth feel without any overtones of alcohol.  An extremely light bitterness lingers.  Nice!

Poured a translucent brown with an off white head that dissipated quickly but left a lot of lacing.  Smells of pine.  Sweet tasting and hard for me to isolate the oak, but really tasty nonetheless.  Solid feel and holds its own against the non-oaked variety.

Pours dark with small but compact head...smells faintly reminiscent of a port and first impressions upon drinking are a solid mouthfeel - pretty chewy with an aftertaste of burnt grain.  Just a touch of bitterness - less so than the aroma implied.  A very good stout - not sure I understand what differentiates an imperial from a standard stout - the abv% isnt super high...a very tasty beer though...

Poured the color of piss on a day with no beer imbibed the night before (i.e. a nice, cloudy yellow) - specks of something(?) floating in pour...nice head - a bit sanitary (i.e. really white looking).  Aroma = best part of this beer...fruity with an emphasis on the banana...goes down smooth with a refreshingly full mouthfeel....definitely not in the same league as your Germanic hefeweizen or dopplebocks, but all in all, a really tasteful alternative to the likes of Hoegarden and other lesser Germanic whites or wheats....

Cmon - you get what you pay for - extremely drinkable (I can pound 8 with no appreciable buzz), no hangover qualities and, face it, it tastes as good as Corona, Modela Especial, any cheap ass malt-liquor, and any other major light - e.g. Coors or Bud.  Granted, its adjuncts in a can, but what were you thinking of when you bought this??  Its not like youre getting something you didnt bargain for...

poured ruby red...small head, but creamy with a lingering lace.  Smells of grapefruit.  Heavy mouth-feel but short of syrupy.  Sweet tasting followed by hop after-taste.  A slight burn going down, but deceptively mild compared to stated abv%.  Yum...

Poured out of a can with the nitrogen(?) laced widget - theyve done a remarkable job bringing the draught pour to a can.  Poured a milky brown settling down into a black brew with a creamy, long lasting head.  Smells of burnt grain and slightly woody.  A little under-carbonated, but smooth.  This beer (bottle) was one of my forays into the land of non-pilsner, and I have an affection for the simple bitterness and uncomplicated bouquet.  Go Irish!

Bottle 476 of 2007 - poured orange out of bottle but cloudy in glass - small head.  Smells boozy - tastes of orange rind and alcohol.  Billed as a barley wine but tastes more like an IPA on steroids - in other words, less of an emphasis on malt and more on hops - and not much subtlety going on with the abv% - this is high octane and tastes/smells like it - maybe this would be bettered aged a while, but I like a lot of their other offerings a lot better.
beer_name: AleWerks Brewmasters Reserve Grand Illumination Ale

review_blob: Bottle 185 of 2007.  Poured dark and thick with a creamy, tan head.  Smells of burnt grain and molasses.  Sweeter up front taste than a lot of porters - maybe due to the eponymous Rapadou sugar??  Tastes thick and leaves a nice, bitter after taste and a bit of coating on the tongue.  A good choice for a cold/cool evening.

Old Foghorn could probably be called Old Faithful - a good barley wine defining the category without coming across as overpowering.  Dark, but not opaque, pour looking more towards a brown ale than a porter.  Molasses similar sweet taste with a stronger smell than taste of hops.  A bit of a slow burn following swallowing - but to be expected with this type of ale.

Hmm, pours with no head and extremely pale.  Smells skunky - Id say it was a bad bottle, but I get the same smell (everytime) I drink Heineken - so I think its purposeful.  <Maybe Im characterizing the smell wrong - is there another name for this type of sour smell??>  Anyway, tastes sweet, a lot like Budweiser (yes, the American one) despite the clear claim that no adjuncts were used.  Sort of the German Corona??  While drinkable, not worth the price.  A (seldom for me) disappointment.

This used to be the only alternative import to Heineken you could get in restaurants before craft/import took off.  Poured a little cloudy and with a finer head (think nitrogen, though I know thats not the case) that dissipated quickly.  A bit more carbonated than a lot of IPAs and a bit of an astringent after taste.  But it has a full mouth feel despite a hint of sourness that, while interesting, doesnt contribute to what I feel the style.  If Heineken was the only other import at the restaurant, Id definitely go with the Bass,,,

Poured dark - almost purple when poured in a pint glass and held up against a florescent light.  Nice head too that remained long after initial pour.  One of the prettiest pours Ive seen.  Smell of burnt grain - a little more like a stout than a porter.  But very well balanced - based on pour, I was afraid it would be too heavy towards the stout side, but the honey mellowed things nicely.  All told, Id buy it again.

Poured a light copper with a little head and decent lacing.  Hops not really discernible and a bit on the sweet side, though not a malty taste.  A little thin and watery for a pale ale - but, kudos to the marketing folks - the best thing that can come out of this beer is converting the masses to try something a little different than the standard American lagers.  This one wont prove too scary :)
beer_name: Green Valley Brewing Stone Mill Pale Ale

review_blob: poured the color of a true pilsner with a bit of haze (too little to call cloudy though the label indicated it was bottle conditioned).  Taste reminded me a lot of Stella Artois with an alcoholic bite.  Yeasty too - in a positive way.  Not bad, just not my favorite style.

poured a beautiful orange with minimal head.  Aromas of pine and grapefruit.  Taste was very balanced - extremely drinkable.  After taste lingered a lot less than many of the hoppier beers Ive had.  I had a 12 oz bottle, but would definitely buy if I saw on tap.  Good brew

poured in a wide bodied red wine glass.  very dark with a small but full bodied head - the color of which is reminiscent of what you might see on top of a root beer float.  Absence of hops smell (duh) and faint aroma of bittersweet chocolate.  Solid mouth feel - a bit chewy.  Im impressed with the blending (as advertised) of the smoked malt, I was expecting it to perhaps overpower - but not the case.  Good beer...
Poured copper with minimal head.  Metallic aftertaste affected my rating by quite a bit.  Best thing about the beer was the label.  Not bad, but nothing to make it stand out from the crowd.

Poured slightly darker than a pale lager.  Head was off white.  I rated the aroma right in the middle because I couldnt really detect much of one (!)  Mouthfeel a little on the fizzy side, but not too gassy.  I think the lime infusion ruined the taste for me - not that it didnt taste like lime, just not my cup of tea.  The label indicated a mix of wheat, but I wasnt able to discern any.
beer_name: Blue Moon Rising Moon Spring Ale

review_blob: My computer blipped - apologies if this turns into a double post.  Didnt realize it was contract brewed - guess that means its not really part of the AB family.  Anyway, poured with a bleach white head that left some lacing - lots of carbonation bubbles visible, but tasted flat - hmm?  Tasted a little sweeter than others in this category and price point - a nice alternative for the Corona crowd.

corked bottle 750ml - poured with a really white head and lemony yellow color reminiscent of some wheats Ive had...a little overly carbonated and fizzy on the tongue - echoes of white wine - a bit astringent.  Best part, in my opinion, was that the abv% was masked - not at all hot or even a hint that it was packing a bit of a punch...with all the Belgians out there to choose from now, I didnt think this one was anything special.
tasty, but nothing special...poured more yellow and less copper than most IPAs.  Sweet taste followed by bitter aftertaste.  A good IPA and not at all betraying the abv.

Smells kinda old coming out of the bottle - like wine left out overnight.  I think what is offputting to me is the mineral content of the brew??  It tastes like the same type of water as a certain English Ale whose name escapes me at the moment, but while that was ok based on the type of brew, it feels out of place here - wish I knew how to express with more precision...just a tad skunky in my opinion.  Not to the point of refusing one, but not much for buying one...
beer_name: Carolina Beer Co. Cottonwood Endo India Pale Ale

review_blob: I was a bit underwhelmed with this brew despite the score.  The underwhelmed is only relative to other Sierra Nevada products - as far as a beer in general, its darn tasty, but I didnt get much of a hop aroma at all in th nose which wouldnt be bad in and of itself but I didnt taste an offsetting amount of malt.  Again, not bad - but probably something Id suggest to someone looking to make the jump from Blue Moon to something a little more crafty without fear of alienation due to too much of an overwhelming presence of hops or malt.  But, again, dont get me wrong. not bad - just not special....

poured thinner than some stouts, but had a head the color of Ovaltine which lasted for a fair amount of time.  Taste was rather middle of the road - definitely not an attempt at overpowering the genre - not as chewy as I would like in a stout, but definite burnt/toasted tastes that made me think Id drink it again...not bad.
UPDATED: MAR 30, 2008

Magnificent pour into a tulip glass - effervescence like a Guinness draught of Bodingtons nitrogen pour sans nitrogen!  Subsided to a mild head with moderate lacing.  Color of a weak bock or mid/heavy IPA - touches of orange...smelled rather bland - a bit of citrus and hint of alcohol.  Mouth-feel = a little flat sort of like the aforementioned can of Boddingtons cream ale - a bit of a disappointment in the carbonation department, but made up for in the taste - although this is an ale, it had a definite wheat beer yeast taste to it - fruity and banana like.  Very minimal alcohol taste.  One interesting (and minimally distracting) side note, the remainder of the head on the beer seemed to coagulate (clot) which was a bit unappetizing yet totally irrelevant to the taste.  A good beer.  One disclaimer though, my bottle looked totally different than what I see displayed - mine was a corked 75 cl bottle - same name but instead of the picture of some dude (like I see on this page), it has a crest - white top/red bottom) depicting a yard of beer.  But, I think its the same thing....

poured pint glass...color of cola - all malt in smell - no discernible hop presence...very sweet - like a dopplebock should be but it seemed to lack much of a presence of anything special in the yeast to offset or complement it.  Very smooth and no overwhelming alcoholic presence despite the higher abv than your average brew.  Pretty tasty - definitely one worth taking a chance on at the store or favorite tap...

Poured in a cabernet glass...thick pour/no lacing or active bubbles...strong aroma of burnt(?) wood with the alcohol content coming through in the nose.  Very sweet - to the point of wondering if they yanked it early from the fermenter to cap the abv %.  Im feeling a bit conflicted regarding this one - on the one hand, I think it would make an impressive complement to a holiday dinner or as an after-dinner digestive to be enjoyed with a good stogie...problem is, thats what I buy fine wine for...as a beer, its too much for me - too sweet, too much alcohol, and too much $.  An unbelievable technical marvel from an awesome brewer but one Im glad Ill say Ive had that - it kicked ass but most likely wont purchase again.  Sort of like being able to brag you rode th latest roller coaster but would just as well live off the memory for a while

not a lot of aroma - decent head but looked a little too sanitized - like dish washing detergent - truthfully advertised though as the honey taste comes through loud and clear - also tasted authentic, by which I mean I tasted a bourbon cask brew by AB that tasted like beer with a teaspoon of vanilla extract - this tasted more like I try to get homebrew to taste...smooth going down with no discernible aftertaste - sort of like a sweeter Shiner Bock

Poured into a wide glass - color of RC Cola - smells a bit like pine sap - decent head.  Sweet with an appropriate bitterness following.  Alcoholic taste comes through - you can tell its got a bit of kick, and I drank mine cold.  Closer to a pale ale than I expected with the hoppiness shining through and through.  Good though...

beer_brewer_name: Schneider Weisse G. Schneider & Sohn GmbH
review_blob: wow - really heavy fruity aroma with a scent of baking bread(!)  You can also smell the alcohol in the background...Solid head - leaves moderate lacing...a bit fizzy but not overpowering...an aftertaste of apples or pears??  The yeast reminds me of a lot of homebrewed wheats Ive tasted - much more fruity than your average bear...a lingering taste of banana follows after the citrus fades.  I didnt detect as much cloves as others have posted - but I may be mingling it in with the fruity deScription in error...this is a fantastic brew.

Pleasantly surprised - billed as an ale - but upon pouring, smells reminiscent of good wheat brews (I guess thats the Belgian aspect for you) - I dinged the appearance because the head looked a little too sterile (color of detergent, like your major American players) - which made for an even more surprising satisfaction with the taste - full bodied, fizzy, but not excessively - sweet, but not overpowering, after-taste lingered quite a while - definitely not powered by adjuncts - I drank 12 oz bottle, but could easily see parking myself on a bar stool and ordering out of the tap all day long...

Pours typical lager color with minimal head - interestingly enough, when I held up to the light, couldnt see much action regarding carbonation bubbles rising to top - but the beer wasnt flat - solid all around brew, I was a bit surprised at the overall rating given by others - I thought this was on par with the crafts put out by the big boys (e.g. Blue Moon) while priced about the same...

Poured very pale - nice aromas but muted relative to other wheats Ive had...smooth taste on tongue, not much going on in terms of carbonation - which is good for this style...sweet aftertaste with a bit of sour lingering - a good summer beer, probably - I just drank it in the winter...

interesting concept - poured in pint glass - had the color of a bock or decent IPA - no foam or lacing.  Sweet tasting - an after taste of cream soda which, while not necessarily unpleasant, tasted a little forced and/or artificial - as if maybe a half a packet of Sweet & Low was added at bottling.  Still, points to A&B; for shrewd marketing and trying to bring a craft experience to the everyman.
